p:
In-vitro antioxidant potential of the different extracts of B. pacumbis was assessed by 1,1-diphenyl 1–2-picryl-hydrazyl (DPPH) assay accordingly with Jha et al. [ 32]. One milliliter of plant extract of different concentrations was added in 3 mL of the DPPH solution (100 mM) and incubated for 30 min in the dark. Absorbance was measured at the wavelength (λ) = 517 nm in a UV-visible spectrophotometer (UV-1800, SHIMADZU). Gallic acid and methanolic DPPH were used as reference and positive control respectively. The following formula was used to calculate percentage of radical scavenging (%RSA).
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \%\mathrm{RSA}=\frac{\ Absorbance\ of\ Control- Absorbance\ of\ Test}{Absorbance\ of\ Control}\ast 100\% $$\end{document}
% RSA =
Absorbance of Control − Absorbance of Test
Absorbance of Control
∗ 100 %
